On Sun, 22 Aug 2004 02:25:38 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> In light of all this I'm going to make a few changes to SharpNEAT, #1
> being the preservation of the fittest species. If  there are several
> species with the maximum species then I will just cull them as normal,
> so I only preserve the fittest species if is the only one. Yeh that
> should work I think. By culling the fittest species I think I was trying
> to achieve to much in the context of a single search, it's better to
> allow the user to decide when a search has stagnated and needs
> resetting. I suppose I could add in a new, 're-start age' parameter that
> detects when the entire search has stagnated for some [large] # of
> generations and resets the population.

I think I understand a little better now how your algorithm is working
and what's going on.  Thanks for the explanation.

Your changes sound pretty sensible, too.

I was just surprised at the extremely large difference in the
progression of fitness in the different complexifying/blended/phased
runs.  From our experience so far, NEAT has proven to be fairly robust
and consistent given changes in parameters and implementation
specifics.

That is, from day one of working with NEAT, we've only ever seen
upward-moving fitness graphs.  Some are flatter than others, but we've
never seen the fitness spike and then plunge.  That seemed like an
extremely odd dynamic for any kind of NEAT run.

Part of your explanation of the dynamics centered on whether or not
the fitness evaluation was deterministic or not.  Per some of the
discussions about adding randomness or noise to the evaluation, this
seems like an important thing to do in almost any domain.  In pattern
recognition, if the fitness evaluation is deterministic, it seems to
me that the networks are much more prone to overfitting to the
training set and are going to be extremely brittle (this aside from
the fact that your crossover function is based on whether or not the
networks have equal fitnesses).

Derek
